official-title.#text: To amend the Higher Education Act of 1965 to provide information to foster youth on their potential eligibility for Federal student aid.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Education and the Workforce

short-title.#text: Foster Youth Higher Education Opportunities Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 483 of the Higher Education Act of 1965

header.#text: Informing foster youth of their potential eligibility for Federal student aid

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall inform each student who indicates on a FAFSA form, in either paper or electronic format, that the student is a foster youth or was in the foster care system of the student's potential eligibility for Federal student aid, including the specific Federal programs under which such student may be eligible to receive assistance such as the John H. Chafee Foster Care Independence Program under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 477 of the Social Security Act

header.#text: Informing foster youth of their potential eligibility for Federal student aid

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 485E(b) of the Higher Education Act of 1965

header.#text: Information for foster youth on Department Web site

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall include on the Department's Web site information for foster youth regarding such youth's potential eligibility for Federal student aid, including the specific Federal programs under which such youth may be eligible to receive assistance.

header.#text: Information for foster youth on department Web site

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HR 2108 IH: Foster Youth Higher Education Opportunities Act

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}rights.#text: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
